text: appearance:  bright yellow, slight haze, a finger of yellow-white head, decent lacing.  aroma: hugely aromatic, with lots of mango, pineapple, grapefruit, white pepper, then some cracker, pie crust, and grass.  taste: 	sweet mango, light mint, pineapple, lemon, orange zest, floral honey, pie crust.  finish: lingering sweetness, balanced by the bitterness of the citrus and floral hops. notes:  Doesnt taste anything like a pilsner or a lager. More like an IPA in the vein of Heady Topper, in that its a similar flavor profile. I prefer my pilsners (and super pilsners) to taste like grass, hay, and pepper. That said, its a good beer.
From tap. Pours hazy orange with a small white head. Aroma is peachy and slight citrusy fruity. Crisp hoppy, fruity, peachy and citrusy. Mellow fuity far finish. Solid peachy and grapefruity.

Hazy yellow orange with small but persistent white head. Aroma fresh orange and grass. Medium body. Light carbonation. Medium body. Flavor juicy and moderately bitter, mostly citrus, a little bit floral, minimal malt but quite pleasant overall.

Tallahassee, Fl - Luckys Market - 16 oz can. Pours a hazy light golden with a blanketed snow white head that leaves a nice coat of lacing, Aroma is fresh and hoppy, full of minty hop, resiny goodness. Flavor has a nice zesty citrus flair to it, some caramel sweetness, a bit of spearmint freshness, a hint of pineapple fruitiness to round it out. Mouthfeel has a solid crispness to it. Solid entrant from Shipyard/Peak.

Can from High St Caffe. Sweet malt/citrus hop aroma with pine. It has a slight malty sweet cloying background to it thats slightly hindering. Oh hell, this beer was delicious and smooth. NE brewing is ramping up rapidly and this is part of the movement. Get on it!

Rraught @ Albion. Cloudy bright yellow with very small frothy white head, piney aroma, medium carbonation, medium bitter citrus peel taste with mango and pineapple, smooth, thin body, medium bitter finish. Nicely hopped and quite smooth.
Can. Pours gold with a thick white head. Big citrus aroma. Lots of hops up front but not overwhelming. This is a strong one but doesn?t come across that way. Pretty good due to the hop mix.

Aroma mango, resin, spruce, citrus, 
Appearance golden, hazy, white foam, 
Taste medium bitterness, 
Palate medium body, 
Overall a nice medium bitter ipa that I would suggest to a friend.

Can after a great round of Disc Golf. Finally parred a hole over 500 ft! Grassy fresh hop aroma with a hint of lemon and pine. LIght malty body with some lemony grassy bitterness and just a touch of pine. Very clean and refreshing. Medium light creamy with fine carbo. The alcohol was hidden well for such a thin beer. Really easy drinker and refreshing!

On tap at Rattle n Hum - East, pours a clear blonde with a small white head. Aroma brings out pungent grassy hops and crisp crackery malt. Aroma is robust, with tons of grassy hops upfront and dominating, with a dry crisp crackery malt backbone. Pungent but elegant. One of the best imperial pilsners out there. Exceptional.

16oz can from CBC, dated 09/09/16. Pours light golden straw with a white head. Aroma is very nice and citrusy... lime, tangerine, grapefruit. Flavor is white bread, a touch of caramel, graoefruit, orange, mango. Nice fruity IPL.

16 oz. can dated 9/9/16. Aroma is real nice, tropical fruit with plenty of grass. Huge mosaic influence. 
Nice pilsner malt that gives a crisp light body. Wow, plenty of mosaic hop influence with maybe a Citra or other hop thrown in there. I am really surprised that this beer is brewed under this label. Very nicely done for the style.

Pours a medium golden color with a huge white pillowy foam. Nose has some nice citrus and tropical fruit notes that play take the front seat with some light wheat notes round out the backend with a touch of sulfur and light spicy yeast. The palate follows with a creamy rich mouthfeel that is lightened by a crisp carbonation and layers of citrus and grass. Yeats profile gets a bit lost in the hop flavors but the clean crisp finish and soft light grain profile make this a smooth drinker !

UPDATED: NOV 11, 2016 Cloudy and dark straw. Earthy nose. Medium to full body, assertively flavorful, low carbonation but nice heat, lingering aftertaste with clean, tasty finish. Crisp, moderate bitterness and surprizing sweetness. Hoppy, resiny, complex, tropical fruit, papaya notes. Delicious, favorite pils. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dry, grassy pilsner characteristics, pine and citrus IPA aromas. Green apple tartness and moderately bitter. Slightly dank and a bit metallic, IMO dank and metallic do not equate to Super Fresh. Very good but not a top flight Strong/DIPL.  Fresh Cut is a far superior product, regardless of the classification (which is getting a bit absurd) of pilsner.

Can from Bethesda Food and Beverage. Nice godlen body with huge head. Nose of toasty, skunky and lots of hops. Taste is grainy, malts, but also well balanced with hops and citrus. Dry in the finish. Just really good.

Clear almost brown pour with thin white head. Very clean, dry pilsner.
dry finish. Very nice.

recently scored can..been looking for this with not much luck..last 4 pack on the shelf..score..dated on bottom 1.28.16 so pretty fresh offering..pours a light orange ipa/dipa color with a massive frothy 3 finger white head..slight haze and particles that sink to bottom of glass..wow the nose here is absolutely wonderful and a sign of quality for sure..cantaloupe..honeydew..mango..lemon/lime zest..juicyfruit gum all rolled together with a trace of strawberry..mouthfeel lives up to the nose and is superb as well..this is not your run of the mill pilsener for sure..has qualities of an ipl/dipa/pilsener..reminds me of the Maine hop profile found in a few Foundation offerings..really enjoyed the layered waves of citrus involved to produce a velvety profile..fresh grass infused with strawberries combined with just the right amount of bitterness to keep palate intrigued and coming in at the perfect abv level..really impressive offering that is one of the better new beers I can remember having in some time...worth seeking out for sure..kudos for the 16 oz can offering as well..

Pours a pale amber from a can, thick white head with lots of lacing. Big floral hop aroma and flavor, is this a new style, like a IIPL or something? Very nice smooth mouthfeel, very crushable, watch out. Very good beer.

Pounder can from Capones. Pours turbid golden with 2-fingers of well retained white head. This one looks like a Maine/Vermont IPA. Nose is...my God, lemme tell ya bout the nose, Bob Griese. A huge olfactory wallop of white peppercorns, mango, honeydew peaches in heavy syrup, and that Maine hop nose that I could bury my nose in for hours. Tastes super smooth, with heavy hop notes, mango, pineapple, white pepper, dry, resiny, hops, and that great Maine/Vermont flavor and finish that is somewhat dry, spicy, floral, and loaded with tropical fruit. This beer reminds me a lot of some of the stuff Hidden River is producing, and is far and away the best beer Peak had ever made. Absolutely flawless!
Can. Fresh hop nose, cat piss, grapefruit, passion fruit. Cloudy pastel gold color with a low, thick head. Good citrus and tropical fruit flavor, biscuit malts, dank and crispy. Good stuff.
16oz can thanks to Mike. pours out a hop hazed golden topped with a white head. nose is citrus hop a nice rich malt. Taste is of the citrus hops a pithy grapefruit bitterness.

16 oz can. Pours out a murky straw color with a minimal whittle head. Aroma is bitter piney hops that presents itself in the flavor as well. Very enjoyable but half a can is as much as I really want. I think the bitterness is a bit overbearing.

16oz can pours slightly hazy orange with a finger of foamy head. Nose is gassy citrus, floral fruit, grapefruit, tangerine. Taste has crisp soft malt, floral orangeblossom honey, grapefruit, grassy citus, medium bitterness. Finishes bitter, grassy grapefruit, mango and orange. Solid.

From the 16 oz. can dated 12/19/15. Slight foggy yellow pour with a tremendous long lasting white foamy head. Lovely aromas of bread, grassy and floral hops. The body falls into the medium range. The taste has all those wonderful German cereal and grainy malt characters one expects from a Pilsener along with a notable but still decently balanced dry hop finish. Right up there among the best.
Pours cloudy gold, big frothy white head. Aroma is grass, citrus, bread, cracker malt, pineapple. Flavor is grass, pissy hop, pineapple and citrus, grass, bread, earth. Med body, nice hoppy clean IPL

16 ounce can. Thanks John. Pours a slightly cloudy gold with a nice white head. Aroma of citrus, grass, and pine. Taste is grapefruit, tropical, grass, pine, and malt. Can says Pilsener, dont know about that. Still, a nice one.
Best I have had from Peak. A good Imperial pils, hoppy...and fresh. Thanks for the hook up Josh.Very drinkable stuff. Foamy lasting head.
16oz can. Poured a yellow color with a white head. Nice and hoppy ... citrus, grassy, floral, with some toasted breadiness.

16oz can. Pours a hazy golden with a white head. Great tasting pilsner similar in taste and character to alot of the IPLs now that have been showing up on the shelf as of late. This is a good one though and well named for the can I tasted anyway.

Smells of rotten tropical fruit in citrus fruit along with a strong mild hot sent finishing off. Taste delicious starts off with a nice crisp refreshing grapefruit mango and pine resin. Taste starts off crisp clean flush with a nice hoppy lemon zest finish. Which the flavor lingered on the tongue a little longer would really make it much more enjoyable you. Peak be one of my favorite main beers keep the brews coming.

Pours a hazy golden with a slightly energetic head which dissipates fairly quickly.....aroma of heavy citrus to grapefruit, slight pine......taste is lemongrass, orange peel, heavier mouthfeel, slightly oily late, grapefruit. The pils malt taste doesnt appear as expected, mostly overpowered by a citra type hop and oiliness of a very slightly overgrained brew. But quite interesting.

Excellent and very fresh, as the title suggests. Frothy head and straw body promises a very well made brew. It doesnt disappoint. The hops are very fresh and zesty-- not unlike an IPA-- but I didnt get the piney, strong and sticky sweetness one would get with an American IPA. Its more refreshing, even at 7.6%. Alcohol stays well hidden, another fine attribute of this quite remarkable beer.

On tap at Sedona, CHO.

Hazy yellow. Taste is floral hops, pine, soap, light other fruits. Quite tasty.

Theres definitely a similarity to hoppy brews being made by New England breweries. Whether its IPA, DIPA, IPL, or in the case of Peak Organic Super Fresh  a pilsner  theres a common thread amongst them. Im not sure this beer truly qualifies as a pilsner per se, but as a beer its quite excellent. Smells great, looks great, tastes great and is easy to drink. Thats what I call an excellent beer.

I poured a 16oz can into a pilsner glass. It was canned on 9/17/15 and cost $4.10 ($0.26 per ounce).

Appearance: A hazy shade of mustard/maize yellow. Spastic effervescence is clearly visible at first, though the more beer I pour into the glass, the hazier the body becomes. Pours to a large, white, foamy head which laces and retains extremely well.

Smell: Huge hop presence of fresh-cut grass as well as tropical fruit juice concentrate. No alcohol presence, though no malt presence, either.

Taste: I dont get too hung up on styles unless Im judging a BJCP-sanctioned event (in which case its mandatory). Im not sure this beer really qualifies as a pilsner considering how its a big beer at 7.6% ABV and also a hop bomb. Its probably better considered an IPL or DIPL; though Ill let the style nerds debate that. What it is, is a highly-hopped, extremely tasty and delectable brew. Slight grassy notes to open the palette with a subtle juicy flavor lurking underneath. At the peak of the swig theres a spicy/herbal note with mild flavors of oregano or basil. The back end is remarkably sweet with a taste akin to an energy drink. The aftertaste is all the spice rack flavors: grassy, spicy, herbal and a dry bitterness that lingers. Obviously, the hops are the star here, and I dont get much in the way of malt distinctiveness. Ill bet some rye would complement the palette perfectly.

Drinkability: I normally associate pilsner with being light in body and alcohol. Peak Organic Super Fresh does have the high carbonation and consistent crispness of a pilsner, though the 7.6% ABV potency is far too heavy to really be true to the style. The mouthfeel is noticeably thicker than most lagers, though the high carbonation makes it vibrate across the tongue. Refreshing while in the mouth, though the aftertaste of spicy hops is a tad cloying. Of course that can be resolved by taking another swig. This is a versatile brew to be sure; strong enough to stand up to all kinds of savory meals, or just enjoy whenever you need a strong hop dosage.

RATING: 10/10

Nice complex aroma of citrus, floral hops, and grassy or bready malt. Very nice looking deep gold body.. slightly cloudy with good carbonation. The flavor is super bitter hoppy right up front but nicely balanced by citrus and bready malt flavors. I enjoy it and hope Peak Organic continues to brew it!

Can from the Quick Stop Londonderry.
Fairly clear deep yellow color with a huge frothy white head that persists forever. Overripe tropical fruit and rind overpower the nose, but eventually some hints of pine and light crackery malt make it through. The flavor is a bit sweeter with bready maltiness and lots of citrus and juicy tropical fruit flavors. The pine is quite subdued in the flavor and would have helped out a bit to cut through some of the sweet flavors here. Still a damn good pilsener right here, glad I bought the intensely white four pack.

Pounder: Grass nose with minty accents and cat pee overtones. Fairly clear amber, thick sticky head. Cat pee, lemongrass. Medium body, alcohol evident. Im not a fan of the hop bill or the concept, but it was well executed.

Can from Brewtopia. Golden with slight chill haze lasting dense head and lace. Grassy fresh hop aroma with a hint of lemon and fresh pastry dough. LIght malty crackery vanilla with some lemony grassy bitterness and just a touch of herbs. Very clean and refreshing. Medium light creamy with fine carbo. Doesnt really feel like a pilsner, but wicked fucking delicious. Excellent in every way. Seriously.

Can thanks to CJ. It pours lightly hazy golden - orange with a thick white head. The nose is fresh, soft lagery malts, dough, hint of sweet corn, grass and some lemon sherbet. The taste is crisp, clean, bitter, quite grassy, light spice, white bread, straw and some alcohol warmth. Medium body and average carbonation. Well rounded and drinkable. Grade A boost-lager.

Pours slightly hazy gold with an off-white head. Both the aroma and the flavor are the delicious citrus and floral hop bomb that you get in regular Fresh Cut. However, boosting the abv adds in some syrupy sweetness and strong alcohol notes. It also adds a sticky and grainy mouthfeel. This is good, and I love the 16 oz can format, but this isnt the slam dunk that is Fresh Cut.

Keg at Sedona Charlottesville. Slightly hazy yellow, large foamy off-white head, decent retention. Aroma of snappy Noble, citrus hops, pale biscuity malt. The taste is citrus, lemon, grassy hops, pale bready malt. Medium bodied, lingering bitterness.
